A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called a system of generators of M if M = sum_{i in I} A x_i.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
Does the concept of a/an System of generators need to be defined for a definition of a/an Free system of generators (basis) to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
To determine if the concept of a system of generators is necessary for the definition of a free system of generators (basis) to make sense, we need to analyze the relationship between these two concepts.

1. A system of generators for an A-module M is defined as a family of elements (x_i)_{i in I} such that every element in M can be expressed as a linear combination of these elements. This means that the set of generators spans the module M.

2. A free system of generators (basis) for an A-module M is defined as a family of elements (x_i)_{i in I} that is not only spanning M (as every element in M can be expressed as a linear combination of these elements) but also linearly independent. Linear independence is defined such that if a linear combination of these elements results in zero, then all the coefficients in this combination must be zero.

3. From the definitions, it is clear that a free system of generators (basis) inherently includes the property of being a system of generators since it spans the module M. However, it adds the additional property of linear independence.

4. Therefore, the concept of a system of generators is implicitly required for the definition of a free system of generators because the latter is an extension of the former. The concept of a free system of generators (basis) would not make sense without first understanding what it means for a set of elements to generate a module (system of generators).
